section: The Term of this Agreement shall be for a period of [* ****] years and [*****] months commencing the 1st day of September 2004 and terminating the [*****] day of [*****].
explanation: The contract specifies a term of [* ****] years and [*****] months, starting September 1, 2004, but fails to provide a specific termination date. This omission creates uncertainty about the agreement's duration, making it difficult to determine the exact period during which the obligations of both parties are in effect.

section: CONSULTANT will be required to be available after a tournament for selected interviews, either the Sunday afternoon or Monday morning following the tournament. In all such interviews and appearances, CONSULTANT will use his best efforts to make reference to the ADAMS GOLF PRODUCT and wear [*****] and display ADAMS GOLF'S brand name.
explanation: This section describes the consultant's obligations during interviews and appearances, including wearing certain apparel. It states the consultant will wear a redacted item '[*****]' and display Adams Golf's brand name. This creates an ambiguity, as the specifics of what apparel needs to be worn by the consultant are unknown.

section: Notwithstanding any other paragraph of this Agreement, in the event that CONSULTANT dies or is unable to play tour golf at all, ADAMS GOLF may terminate this Agreement on thirty (30) days' written notice. Upon such termination, CONSULTANT and/or CONSULTANT'S estate shall be required to repay ADAMS GOLF for that period of the Agreement not performed by CONSULTANT. The repayment amount shall be calculated in the same way as repayment is calculated under paragraph 8A.
explanation: This section outlines the consequences of termination due to the consultant's death or inability to play golf, including a repayment obligation. However, Paragraph 8A, which dictates the repayment schedule, is based on the *failure* to play in a certain number of tournaments. Applying this schedule to a scenario where the consultant has died or is permanently unable to play is illogical and creates an unenforceable condition, as they are vastly different scenarios.
